questions.text: An 8-year-old child had fracture of humerus 2 years back. Now he’s having difficulty in hanging his school bag. There is also a presence of the shown deformity. What can be the most likely injury? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Supracondylar humerus fracture

 

  • The deformity seen in the image associated with supracondylar fracture of the humerus is commonly referred to as a "Gunstock deformity" or cubitus varus.
  • This deformity occurs due to malunion of the fracture, where the distal fragment of the humerus heals in a position that causes the elbow to angle inward toward the body.
  • The name "gunstock" comes from the appearance resembling the shape of a rifle's butt.
  • The anatomical distortion results from an improper alignment of the fracture during healing, often due to inadequate reduction or stabilization at the time of initial treatment.
  • This leads to a visible and functional deformity where the extended arm appears deviated towards the midline of the body, affecting the natural alignment and motion of the elbow.
  • This can also impact the arm's functionality, such as difficulty in activities that require extending the arm fully or placing load on it, like hanging a school bag.

 

Other Options:

 

Option. A. Lateral Condyle Humerus Fracture: Often involves the growth plate and can lead to deformity if not properly treated. The most common sequela of non-union with displacement of this fracture is the development of progressive cubitus valgus deformity. Cubitus varus is the reported complication following lateral condyle fracture malunion after surgical intervention.

 

 

Option. B. Olecranon Fracture: Typically impacts elbow extension and would not generally cause problems with shoulder or arm suspension like hanging a bag. If the fracture is displaced there may be marked deformity at the elbow with a palpable gap. The hallmark of an olecranon fracture is the inability to extend the elbow against gravity. 

 

Option. D. Posterior Dislocation of Elbow: Would cause more immediate and severe movement restrictions and is less likely to present with delayed symptoms related to hanging a bag.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gunstock deformity or cubitus varus is seen in children with history of supracondylar fracture humerus.

questions.text: The Warburg effect refers to: (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Aerobic glycolysis

 

Explanation:

 

The Warburg effect occurs in cancer cells and represents a paradoxical phenomenon where, even in the presence of oxygen, glucose is converted to lactate. This is termed "aerobic glycolysis" because it occurs under aerobic conditions, yet results in lactate production (which normally happens under anaerobic conditions). The Warburg effect involves a metabolic shift where cancer cells produce ATP predominantly through glycolysis followed by lactate formation, rather than through the more efficient oxidative phosphorylation pathway, despite oxygen availability.

 

In cancer cells with Warburg effect, the end-product is lactate and only 2 ATPs are formed, compared to the normal aerobic metabolism which would yield much more ATP through complete oxidation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Anaerobic glycolysis: This is the normal process of glucose conversion to lactate in the absence of oxygen. The Warburg effect is distinct because it occurs even when oxygen is present.

 

Option C. Sustained angiogenesis: This refers to the formation of new blood vessels to support tumor growth, which is a hallmark of cancer but not related to the Warburg effect.

 

Option D. Evasion of apoptosis: This describes cancer cells' ability to avoid programmed cell death, another hallmark of cancer but unrelated to the metabolic shift described by the Warburg effect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Warburg effect is a critical metabolic adaptation in cancer cells where they preferentially convert glucose to lactate even in oxygen-rich environments, resulting in reduced ATP production but providing metabolic advantages for rapid proliferation and contributing to cancer-associated weight loss (cachexia).

questions.text: The three most important enzymes regulating the Citric Acid Cycle include all of the following, except: (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Aconitase

 

Explanation:

 

The three rate-limiting enzymes/steps in the TCA cycle are specifically listed as: 1) Citrate synthase, 2) α-KG DH (alpha-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase), and 3) Isocitrate Dehydrogenase. Aconitase catalyzes the conversion of citrate to isocitrate but is not mentioned among the key regulatory enzymes of the cycle.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Citrate synthase: This is incorrect as an answer because it is one of the three main regulatory enzymes of the TCA cycle. It is specifically identified as one of the regulatory enzymes.

 

Option B. Isocitrate dehydrogenase: This is incorrect as an answer because it is one of the three main regulatory enzymes of the TCA cycle. This enzyme is a key regulatory component.

 

Option C. Alpha-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase: This is incorrect as an answer because it is one of the three main regulatory enzymes of the TCA cycle. It is clearly identified as one of the regulatory steps.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The three major regulatory enzymes of the TCA cycle are citrate synthase, isocitrate dehydrogenase, and alpha-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase, while aconitase serves as a non-regulatory enzyme in the pathway.

choices.text: Must be distinguished from Pulsus Alternans
Is a sign of digitalis toxicity

questions.text: All of the following statements about Pulsus Bigeminus are true, except? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Compensatory pause is absent

 

Explanation:

 

Pulsus bigeminus is characterized by a normal beat followed by a premature ventricular contraction (PVC), creating a pattern where every other beat appears weaker. This creates an alternating strong-weak pulse pattern. Importantly, PVCs typically have a compensatory pause following them, as the ventricle is refractory to the next normal sinus impulse.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Must be distinguished from Pulsus Alternans:  Pulsus bigeminus must be distinguished from pulsus alternans as they present differently. Pulsus alternans is associated with severe left ventricular dysfunction, while pulsus bigeminus is due to premature beats.

 

Option B. Is a sign of digitalis toxicity: Digitalis toxicity can produce various dysrhythmias including premature ventricular contractions in a bigeminal pattern. It's a classic manifestation of digoxin toxicity.

 

Option D. Rhythm is irregular: Pulsus bigeminus demonstrates an irregular rhythm with normal sinus beats interrupted by premature ventricular contractions.

 

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Pulsus bigeminus is an irregular cardiac rhythm characterized by normal beats alternating with premature ventricular contractions, which are typically followed by compensatory pauses as the ventricle is refractory to the next sinus impulse.

questions.text: Post-translational modification common to collagen, hemoglobin, and immunoglobulin? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Subunit aggregation

 

Post-translational modifications occur after the synthesis of a protein and are crucial for the protein to attain its functional form. Subunit aggregation is a process that involves the assembly of multiple protein subunits to form a functional complex. This process is common to several proteins, including collagen, hemoglobin, and immunoglobulin:

 

  • Collagen forms a triple helix structure by aggregating three polypeptide chains.
  • Hemoglobin is composed of two alpha and two beta globin chains that come together to form a functional protein capable of oxygen transport.
  • Immunoglobulins are composed of heavy and light chains that must aggregate to form the functional antibody.

 

Thus, the common post-translational modification among these proteins is subunit aggregation, where individual protein subunits come together to create a functional unit.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Splicing: This is a post-transcriptional modification that occurs at the RNA level, not at the protein level. It involves the removal of introns from pre-mRNA and is not related to post-translational modifications.

 

Option B. Gene editing: Gene editing involves altering the DNA sequence, which occurs before transcription and translation. It is not a post-translational modification and does not pertain to protein processing.

 

Option D. Hydroxylation: Hydroxylation is a post-translational modification that specifically applies to collagen. It involves the addition of hydroxyl groups to proline and lysine residues, a process that requires vitamin C. However, hydroxylation is not a common modification across collagen, hemoglobin, and immunoglobulins, which makes it an incorrect answer in this context.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Subunit aggregation is a post-translational modification common to collagen, hemoglobin, and immunoglobulin, where multiple protein subunits assemble to form a functional protein complex.

questions.text: Identify the deficiency of the nutrient as given in the image of a child: (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Zinc deficiency

 

The image shows acrodermatitis enteropathica, which is a characteristic manifestation of zinc deficiency. This condition presents with skin manifestations along with other symptoms like diarrhea, brittle nails, and in severe cases can lead to sterility in older patients. The skin lesions typically appear as eczematous and psoriasiform plaques in acral and periorificial locations.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option B. Vitamin A deficiency: Incorrect because Vitamin A deficiency primarily manifests as xerophthalmia with ocular changes like Bitot's spots, night blindness, and corneal changes, not the skin manifestations shown in the image.

 

Option C. Vitamin C deficiency: Incorrect because Vitamin C deficiency (scurvy) presents with bleeding gums, poor wound healing, and petechial hemorrhages, not the characteristic skin lesions shown.

 

Option D. Copper deficiency: Incorrect because copper deficiency (pseudoscurvy) has different manifestations including anemia and neurological symptoms, not the skin manifestations shown in the image.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Characteristic skin manifestations of acrodermatitis enteropathica as a sign of zinc deficiency, which includes eczematous lesions accompanied by systemic symptoms like diarrhea and brittle nails.

choices.text: ½ of total energy and ½ of protein
⅓ of total energy and ½ of protein
½ of total energy and ⅓ of protein
⅓ of total energy and ⅓ of protein

questions.text: Meals under the Mid-day Meal Program (MDMP) should provide?[NEET PG 2015]
questions.solution:
Ans.  (b) ⅓ of total energy and ½ of protein

 

  • In formulating mid-day meals for school children, the established principle is that the meal should supply at least one-third of the total energy requirement, and half of the protein need. 
  • This balanced approach ensures the meal serves as an effective nutritional supplement without becoming a complete substitute for home diet, making it both nutritionally adequate and practically implementable.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. ½ of total energy and ½ of protein: The energy proportion is overstated. Providing half of daily energy requirements would make the meal too substantial and potentially costly.

 

Option C. ½ of total energy and ⅓ of protein: This option incorrectly reverses the proportions of both nutrients.

 

Option D. ⅓ of total energy and ⅓ of protein: While the energy proportion is correct, the protein requirement is understated. Growing children need more protein proportionally.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The mid-day meal program balances nutritional adequacy with practical implementation by focusing more heavily on protein (½ of daily needs) while providing moderate energy support (⅓ of daily needs) to school children.

questions.text: What is the active principle of the poison shown in the image? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Bhilawanol

 

  • The above image shows the seeds of Semicarpus anacardium
  • Identification: Black, heart-shaped seeds with a rough projection at the base
  • Active principles: bhilawanol and semicarpol.
  • Common name: Marking nut
  • Uses of the juice:
    • To produce an artificial bruise.
    • Juice is used by washerman/laundries to inscribe identification number on the clothes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ricin: Ricin is a highly toxic protein found in the seeds of the castor oil plant (Ricinus communis).

 

Option C. Abrin: Abrin is a toxic protein found in the seeds of the rosary pea (Abrus precatorius).

 

Option D. Calotropin: Calotropin is a cardiac glycoside found in the milkweed plant (Calotropis gigantea).

 

Educational Objective:

 

The active principle of the marking nut (Semicarpus anacardium) is Bhilawanol, used in traditional practices for its staining and toxic properties.

choices.text: History of similar illness in the past

questions.text: A man from Chhattisgarh presented with a gradual onset of muscle weakness and spasms in his legs. Upon examination, he exhibited a specific loss of motor function. What inquiries should be made to gather the most relevant medical history from this patient? [NEET PG 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) History of diet

 

  • The clinical presentation suggests that the patient may have neurolathyrism, which is caused by the excessive consumption of Lathyrus sativus or Khesari dal.
  • To confirm the diagnosis, it is important to obtain the patient's dietary history.
  • Neurolathyrism is a paralytic condition caused by the consumption of Lathyrus sativus or Khesari dal, which is common in certain regions of India such as Madhya Pradesh, Uttar Pradesh, Chhattisgarh, Odisha, and Bihar.
  • The disease mainly affects the nervous system, causing gradual spastic paralysis of the lower limbs. It primarily affects males between the ages of 15 and 45 years and progresses through several stages.
  • The toxin responsible for the disease is BOAA (Beta oxalyl amino alanine), which is water-soluble and can be removed from the pulses by soaking them in hot water and discarding the water.
  • Large-scale detoxification can be achieved by parboiling the crop, or by overnight soaking in lime water followed by boiling.
  • Vitamin C in doses of 500-1000mg can help prevent and treat lathyrism.
  • In India, the Prevention of Food Adulteration Act prohibits the use of Lathyrus sativus in any form (whole/split/flour).

 

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Painful arc syndrome is seen in:(NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Mid-abduction

 

IMPINGEMENT SYNDROME

 

  • It is soft tissues entrapment.
  • Tendinitis of the rotator cuff is the major cause of a painful shoulder.
  • The rotator cuff consists of the tendons of the supraspinatus, infraspinatus, subscapularis, and teres minor muscles, and inserts on the humeral tuberosity.
  • The supraspinatus tendon is the most often affected, probably because of its repeated impingement between the humeral head and the undersurface of the anterior third of the acromion and coracoacromial ligament above as well as the reduction in its blood supply that occurs with abduction of the arm. This phenomenon is described as impingement syndrome.
  • The process begins with edema and hemorrhage of the rotator cuff which evolves to fibrotic thickening and eventually to rotator cuff degeneration with tendon tears and bone spurs.
  • Subacromial bursitis also accompanies this syndrome.
  • Symptoms usually appear after injury or overuse, especially with activities involving elevation of the arm with some degree of forward flexion.
  • Impingement syndrome occurs in persons participating in baseball, tennis, swimming, or occupations that require repeated elevation of the arm.
  • Severe pain is experienced when the arm is actively abducted into an overhead position. The arc between 60° and 120° (mid-range abduction) is especially painful. This is also described as “painful arc syndrome”.
  • NSAIDs, local glucocorticoid injection, and physical therapy may relieve symptoms.
  • Surgical decompression of the subacromial space may be necessary in patient refractory to conservative treatment

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Initial abduction: Incorrect, as the pain typically does not start at the beginning of abduction but becomes noticeable as the arm reaches mid-range.

 

Option C. Full range of abduction: Incorrect, although the entire range might be uncomfortable, the specific "painful arc" is usually observed in the mid-range.

 

Option D. Overhead abduction: Incorrect, as the term "painful arc syndrome" specifically refers to pain experienced in the mid-range of abduction, not necessarily when the arm is fully overhead.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Painful arc syndrome, a clinical manifestation of impingement syndrome, is observed during mid-range shoulder abduction, typically between 60° and 120°. This condition is often seen in individuals engaging in activities that involve repeated arm elevation, and management may include NSAIDs, corticosteroid injections, physical therapy, or, in refractory cases, surgical intervention to decompress the subacromial space.

questions.text: Middle radioulnar joint is a type of: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Syndesmosis

 

The middle radioulnar joint is a fibrous joint where the radius and ulna are connected along their shafts by an interosseous membrane. This type of joint, where the bones are joined by a ligament or a sheet of fibrous tissue, is classified as a syndesmosis. This allows for some movement between the bones while still providing a strong connection.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Symphysis: A symphysis is a type of cartilaginous joint where the bones are joined by fibrocartilage. This is not applicable to the middle radioulnar joint, which is connected by fibrous tissue rather than cartilage.

 

Option B. Synostosis: Synostosis refers to a condition where two bones fuse together, which is not the case with the middle radioulnar joint. This joint maintains a fibrous connection between the bones, not a bony fusion.

 

Option C. Synchondrosis: A synchondrosis is a type of cartilaginous joint where bones are joined by hyaline cartilage. This type of joint is typically found in growth plates, not in the middle radioulnar joint.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The middle radioulnar joint is classified as a syndesmosis, which is a type of fibrous joint connected by a sheet of fibrous tissue, such as the interosseous membrane.

questions.text: Quadruple testing is done during? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 15-20 weeks

 

Explanation:

 

Quadruple testing, also known as the quadruple screen or quad screen, is typically performed between 15-20 weeks of pregnancy, with the most accurate results obtained between 16-18 weeks. The test measures four serum analytes:

 

  • Maternal serum alpha-fetoprotein (MSAFP)
  • Unconjugated estriol (uE3)
  • Free Beta-hCG
  • Inhibin-A

 

This test helps assess the risk of certain chromosomal abnormalities such as Down syndrome (trisomy 21) and trisomy 18, as well as neural tube defects. The quad screen has a lower sensitivity compared to the first trimester combined screening (which includes nuchal translucency and dual marker screening), making it particularly useful for women who present for prenatal care later in pregnancy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 9-11 weeks: This timeframe is generally used for first trimester screening tests, such as the combined screening, which includes nuchal translucency and the dual marker test (free β-hCG and PAPP-A).

 

Option B. 12-14 weeks: This period is also used for the combined first trimester screening but is not appropriate for the quad screen.

 

Option D. 22-28 weeks: This period is outside the recommended timeframe for the quad screen. Tests in this period are more focused on gestational diabetes screening and routine ultrasounds.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The quadruple test is performed between 15-20 weeks of pregnancy to screen for chromosomal abnormalities and neural tube defects.

 

 

Easy to remember: In Down Syndrome, Beta hCG and Inhibin A are increases (B – Big; B in Beta hCG, B in Inhibin A)

 

*King Edward Abdicated his throne so all levels are decreased

questions.text: A 51-year-old woman who had an abdominal hysterectomy two years ago and is now experiencing abdominal pain, vomiting bile, high-pitched bowel sounds during examination. The presence of air within the biliary tree is seen on diagnostic tests. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Gallstone ileus

 

The given clinical scenario is suggestive of intestinal obstruction. Though adhesions could be the reason, the presence of air in biliary tree makes a diagnosis of gallstone ileus more likely.

 

  • Gallstone ileus is a rare complication of cholelithiasis, occurring due to the impaction of gallstones in the gastrointestinal tract. This occurs due to chronic gall bladder inflammation and formation of cholecysto-duodenal fistula (GB to duodenum). Through the communication, a gall stone may pass into the duodenum and then into small bowel.
  • Small gallstones may pass through the intestines spontaneously, but larger stones (2-5 cm) are more likely to cause obstruction, usually at the terminal ileum or ileocecal valve.
  • Symptoms may include acute, intermittent, or chronic episodes of gastrointestinal obstruction, abdominal distension and tenderness, high-pitched bowel sounds, and obstructive jaundice.
  • Diagnosis is typically made with a plain abdominal radiograph, which may show signs of obstruction, Pneumobilia (air within the biliary tree), and a gallstone in the intestines (RIGLER’S TRIAD).
  • Treatment involves surgical intervention, with a longitudinal incision made on the antimesenteric border to remove the gallstone.

 

 Other Options:

 

Option B. Adhesive intestinal obstruction: This results from the formation of adhesions (bands of scar tissue) that can develop after surgery, which then bind the intestines together. These adhesions can pull the intestines out of place or create a kink or twist. The patient's history of an abdominal hysterectomy is suggestive of this, as post-surgical adhesions are a common cause of intestinal obstruction. However, the presence of air in the biliary tree does not fit with this diagnosis.

 

Option C. Ischemic enterocolitis: Refers to inflammation of the intestine due to reduced blood supply, often caused by blockage or constriction of the blood vessels that serve the intestines. Symptoms typically include sudden abdominal pain and bloody diarrhea. While ischemic processes can cause pain and altered bowel sounds, the presence of pneumobilia on imaging is not consistent with ischemic enterocolitis.

 

Option D. Diverticulitis: Diverticulitis is the inflammation of one or more diverticula, which are small pouches that can form in the walls of the colon. Symptoms include lower left-sided abdominal pain, fever, and changes in bowel habits. While diverticulitis can lead to complications like abscesses, fistulas, or bowel obstructions, the specific presentation of vomiting bile and air within the biliary tree on imaging is not consistent with a primary diagnosis of diverticulitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Gallstone ileus is a rare complication of cholelithiasis characterized by the presence of air within the biliary tree, obstructive symptoms, and the formation of a cholecysto-duodenal fistula.
  • It typically presents with signs of gastrointestinal obstruction and is diagnosed through imaging, revealing pneumobilia and a gallstone in the intestines.

questions.text: Which of the following can be mediated by CRISPR CAS 9 technology? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) DNA editing

 

CRISPR-Cas9 technology is a powerful tool used for DNA editing. It works by creating double-strand breaks in the DNA at specific locations. The CRISPR (Clustered Regularly Interspersed Short Palindromic Repeats) component guides the Cas9 endonuclease to the precise cutting site within the genome. Once the DNA is cut, the cell’s natural repair mechanisms are used to add, delete, or replace genetic material at the targeted site, enabling precise editing of the DNA sequence.

 

CRISPR-Cas9 is derived from a natural immune system in bacteria, which uses this mechanism to defend against bacteriophages by cutting their DNA. In genetic engineering, this system has been harnessed for various applications, including gene deletion, exogenous gene insertion, and multigene editing, all of which involve altering the DNA sequence in a targeted manner.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. DNA replication: CRISPR-Cas9 does not play a role in DNA replication, which is the process by which DNA is copied before cell division. DNA replication is managed by other cellular machinery, including DNA polymerases.

 

Option B. Post-transcriptional modification: This involves changes to RNA after it has been transcribed from DNA, such as splicing, editing, or polyadenylation. CRISPR-Cas9 does not mediate these processes; it specifically targets DNA.

 

Option C. DNA induction: This term is not commonly used in the context of molecular biology, and it does not apply to CRISPR-Cas9 technology. CRISPR-Cas9 is specifically used for editing DNA, not for inducing or initiating processes within the DNA.

 

Educational Objective:

 

CRISPR-Cas9 technology is primarily used for precise DNA editing, enabling targeted modifications to the genetic code

questions.text: A traveler consumed oysters. He later presented with bloody diarrhea, abdominal pain, and vomiting. The organism seen on microscopy exhibited Kanagawa phenomenon. The likely causative organism is: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Vibrio parahaemolyticus

 

Vibrio parahaemolyticus is a salt-loving organism commonly associated with seafood consumption, particularly raw or undercooked oysters. It can cause gastroenteritis characterized by symptoms like watery or bloody diarrhea, abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting. The Kanagawa phenomenon, which is the hemolysis of human red blood cells on a special medium, is specifically linked with Vibrio parahaemolyticus, further confirming its presence in this case. This bacterium's name also hints at its association with blood ("hemolyticus"), which aligns with the symptoms of bloody diarrhea seen in this patient.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Staphylococcus aureus: This organism typically causes food poisoning with symptoms like nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea, but it is not associated with bloody diarrhea or the Kanagawa phenomenon. It is also not specifically related to seafood.

 

Option B. Salmonella typhi: This organism causes typhoid fever, characterized by prolonged fever, abdominal pain, and constipation or diarrhea, but not typically bloody diarrhea or the Kanagawa phenomenon. It is also not linked with seafood consumption or being salt-loving.

 

Option D. Vibrio cholera: While Vibrio cholera is associated with severe watery diarrhea, it does not cause bloody diarrhea or present with the Kanagawa phenomenon. Vibrio cholera also differs from Vibrio parahaemolyticus in its clinical presentation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vibrio parahaemolyticus is the likely cause of gastroenteritis with bloody diarrhea following the consumption of oysters, and it exhibits the Kanagawa phenomenon on microscopy.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male complained of gradual swelling around the wrist for 3 months. X-ray is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Giant cell tumor

 

GIANT-CELL TUMOR (OSTEOCLASTOMA)

 

  • It is the bone lesion of uncertain origin, most commonly seen in distal femur, proximal tibia, proximal humerus and distal radius.
  • Tumor of lower end radius is GCT till proved otherwise.
  • Most commonly seen in 20-40 years of age, after epiphyseal fusion.
  • There is a slight female predominance.
  • Only tumour that can involve the joints and cartilage
  • GCT has 2 types of cells:
    • Giant cells
    • Mononuclear cells: Malignant cells
       
  • Histology: 
    • Multinucleated giant cells are seen on a background of stromal cells with little or no visible intercellular tissue.
    • The nuclei of the mononuclear cells are identical to the nuclei of giant cells – A feature that helps to distinguish giant cell tumor from other tumors that may contain giant cells.
       
  • GCT has egg shell crackling on palpation.
  • Although these tumors typically are benign, pulmonary metastases occur in approximately 3% of patients.
  • Malignant giant cell tumors represent less than 5% of total GCT.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Most commonly presents with pain, with or without swelling.
    • Pathological fracture occurs in 10-15% of cases.
    • Pulmonary metastasis occurs in 4% of cases, but they usually regress spontaneously.
       
  • Radiological Features:
    • Eccentric lytic lesion at epiphyseal region with distinct margins, bounded by subchondral bone plate, with soap bubble appearance, without any calcifications & reactive sclerosis
       
  • Treatment:
    • Curettage and ‘stripping’ of the cavity, followed by swabbing with hydrogen peroxide or by the application of liquid nitrogen.
    • More aggressive tumors and recurrent lesions: Excision followed by bone grafting.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Osteoid osteoma. It is commonest benign true bone tumor. The patient has pain that is worse at night and is relieved by aspirin or other NSAID medications. When the lesion is in a vertebra, scoliosis may occur. Both Osteoblastic & Osteoclastic cells are seen. The lesion has central lysis with surrounding sclerosis. Growing center is called as Nidus (Seed). It is most common in diaphysis of femur. CT is the best study to identify the nidus and confirm the diagnosis. D/D of osteoid osteoma is bone island. Radiofrequency ablation is used for osteoid osteoma. Surgical management involves removal of the entire nidus done by burr-down technique.

 

 

Option C. Osteosarcoma. Osteosarcoma is a radiation-induced sarcoma. It is characterized by the production of osteoid matrix by malignant cells. It is the second most common primary malignancy of bone after multiple myeloma. It is most commonly seen in the distal femur, proximal tibia, and proximal humerus. All patients report progressive pain. Night pain is also reported in about 25% patients. Characteristic findings are Codman’s triangle and Sunburst periosteal reaction. It is the most radioresistant bone tumor and treated by chemotherapy followed by limb salvage surgery/amputation followed by chemotherapy.

 

 

Option D. Ewing’s sarcoma. Ewing sarcoma is the fourth most common primary malignancy of bone, but it is the second most common (after osteosarcoma) in patients younger than 30 years of age and the most common in patients younger than 10 years of age. Its maximum incidence is seen in 2nd decade of life. Pain is an almost universal complaint of patients. In addition to pain, patients also may have fever, erythema, and swelling suggesting osteomyelitis. Laboratory studies may reveal increased WBC count, an elevated ESR, and an elevated CRP. Classically, Ewing sarcoma appears radiographically as a destructive lesion in the diaphysis of a long bone with an “onion skin” periosteal reaction. Ewing sarcoma more often originates in the metaphysis of a long bone, but frequently extends for a considerable distance into the diaphysis. Lung is the most common site of metastases. The worst prognostic factor is the presence of distant metastases. Even with aggressive treatment, patients with metastases have only a 20% chance of long-term survival. The treatment include neoadjuvant or adjuvant chemotherapy, or both, to treat distant metastases. Chemotherapy is much more effective and include vincristine, actinomycin D, cyclophosphamide, bleomycin, adriamycin, ifosfamide and etoposide.

 

  • ABCD: Actinomycin D / Bleomycin / Cyclophosphamide / Doxorubicin
  • Best results are achieved by Preoperative chemotherapy; then wide excision (or amputation) if tumor is in favorable site and further chemotherapy for 1 year. Subsequently Radiotherapy may be given.

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The x-ray image shown in the question is diagnostic of Giant cell tumor of the distal end of radius.
  • Tumor of distal end radius is GCT, until proved otherwise.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most reliable marker for diagnosing Acute STEMI specifically in athletes? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Troponin T or I

 

Cardiac troponins (specifically troponin I and T) are the most sensitive and specific markers for myocardial necrosis in acute coronary syndromes, including STEMI. Troponin I and T are the preferred biomarkers for diagnosing myocardial injury, with Troponin I having slightly higher cardiac specificity than Troponin T. These biomarkers remain the diagnostic standard regardless of patient population, including athletes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CK-MB: While CK-MB is a cardiac marker, it is less sensitive than troponin. It returns to baseline in 48-72 hours and serves better as a marker for re-infarction rather than initial diagnosis. It's problematic in athletes specifically because skeletal muscle damage from exercise can elevate CK-MB, reducing its diagnostic specificity.

Option C. C-reactive Protein: CRP is a general inflammatory marker but lacks specificity for cardiac damage. It has no established role in the primary diagnosis of STEMI.

 

Option D. LDH: LDH is characterized as a "Late Cardiac Marker" that undergoes an "LDH flip" (LDH1 > LDH2) in MI. However, it rises too late in the course of myocardial injury to be useful for early diagnosis, and has poor specificity for cardiac damage compared to troponins.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Troponin I and T remain the gold standard biomarkers for diagnosing myocardial infarction, including STEMI, due to their high cardiac specificity and sensitivity, even in athletic populations where other markers may be elevated from exercise.

choices.text: 1- right kidney, 2- pancreas, 3- left kidney

questions.text: Identify the structures marked. (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans.  D) 1- liver 2-spleen 3-pancreas

 

Explanation:

 

 

Other Option:

 

Option D: 1- liver, 2- spleen, 3- pancreas: Correct based on organ anatomy and typical CT appearance.

 

Educational Objective :

 

Accurate identification of abdominal organs on imaging studies like CT scans is essential for diagnosing diseases, planning surgeries, and tracking treatment progress.

questions.text: In methanol poisoning, which of these is increased in the blood? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Formic acid and lactic acid


Methanol poisoning occurs when methanol is metabolized in the body. Methanol is first converted to formaldehyde, which is then further metabolized to formic acid. Formic acid is toxic and interferes with cellular respiration, inhibiting the normal production of ATP. This interference pushes the body towards anaerobic metabolism, leading to the accumulation of lactic acid in the blood. Therefore, in methanol poisoning, both formic acid and lactic acid levels are elevated due to disrupted cellular respiration and subsequent anaerobic metabolism.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Formic acid and glycolic acid: Glycolic acid is primarily associated with ethylene glycol poisoning, not methanol poisoning. In methanol poisoning, formic acid is the primary metabolite responsible for toxicity.

 

Option B. Oxalic and formic acid: Oxalic acid is a major toxic metabolite of ethylene glycol, not methanol. In methanol poisoning, formic acid is the main toxic substance, and oxalic acid does not play a role.

 

Option C. Glycolic and lactic acid: Glycolic acid is related to ethylene glycol poisoning, not methanol poisoning. While lactic acid can be elevated due to anaerobic metabolism, glycolic acid is not a product of methanol metabolism.

 

Educational Objective:


In methanol poisoning, formic acid and lactic acid levels increase due to disrupted cellular respiration and anaerobic metabolism.

questions.text: Which of the following refractory condition is depicted in the figure.  (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Astigmatism

 

Astigmatism occurs when the cornea or lens has an irregular shape, preventing light from focusing properly on the retina. This leads to blurred or distorted vision at all distances. Common symptoms include eyestrain, headaches, and difficulty seeing at night.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Presbyopia: This is a common condition associated with aging, where the eye's lens loses its ability to change shape to focus on close objects. Symptoms include difficulty reading small print or having to hold reading material farther away. Presbyopia typically starts to become noticeable in the early to mid-40s.

 

Option B. Myopia (Nearsightedness): This condition occurs when the eye is longer than normal or has a cornea that is too curved. As a result, light rays focus in front of the retina instead of on it. This leads to distant objects appearing blurry while close objects are seen clearly. Myopia is often identified in childhood or adolescence and can worsen during periods of rapid growth.

 

Option D. Hypermetropia (Farsightedness): In this condition, the eye is shorter than normal, or the cornea is not curved enough, causing light to focus behind the retina. This makes close objects appear blurry, while distant objects are usually seen clearly. Children often have some degree of hypermetropia, which can decrease as the eye grows and lengthens.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognizing and understanding these refractive conditions is essential for early detection and management. Regular eye examinations are crucial, as they allow for the timely prescription of corrective lenses or other treatments. Each condition affects vision in a unique way, and understanding these differences is key in providing effective patient care and guidance.

questions.text: Match the following:  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1-d, 2-c, 3-b, 4-a

 

The correct matching of the diseases with their diagnostic techniques is as follows:

 

  1. Leprosy - d. Split skin smear
  2. Tinea capitis - c. KOH wet mount
  3. Contact dermatitis - b. Patch test
  4. Lupus vulgaris - a. Biopsy

 

Other options:

 

The other options provided in the multiple choice (A, B, and C) are incorrect matchings of the diseases and diagnostic techniques.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Each skin condition has a specific diagnostic test:

 

  • Leprosy is diagnosed using a split skin smear, typically from the earlobe.
  • Tinea capitis, a fungal infection, is diagnosed using a KOH wet mount of skin, nail, or hair scrapings.
  • Contact dermatitis is evaluated using a patch test to identify allergens.
  • Lupus vulgaris, a form of cutaneous tuberculosis, is diagnosed through a skin biopsy to look for granulomas.

questions.text: Based on the symptoms reported by the patient, what could be the possible diagnosis for a 30-year-old man who has been experiencing recurrent discharge and pain due to lesions around the anus for the past four years? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Fistula in ano

 

  • A fistula in ano is an abnormal tract or channel that develops between the anal canal and the skin around the anus.
  • It is usually caused by an infected anal gland or abscess that fails to heal.
  • The symptoms of a fistula in ano may include pain, swelling, discharge of pus or blood, and recurrent abscesses around the anus.
  • Diagnosis of a fistula in ano is typically made by a physical examination and medical history review.
  • Imaging studies such as MRI or ultrasound may also be used to determine the extent and location of the fistula.
  • Given the patient's chronic history of recurrent discharge and pain around the anus for four years, a fistula in ano is the most likely diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pilonidal sinus: A pilonidal sinus is a small cyst or abscess that occurs in the cleft at the top of the natal cleft. It often contains hair and skin debris. Common symptoms include pain, redness, and swelling in the area of the buttocks crease, and sometimes it can release pus. Given that the patient's symptoms are around the anus and involve recurrent discharge and pain for several years, a pilonidal sinus, which primarily occurs in the cleft of the buttocks, is less likely.

 

Option B. Carbuncle: A carbuncle is an infective gangrene seen on the back or chest wall. Carbuncles can lead to the formation of an abscess, and symptoms might include a lump filled with pus, which might weep or ooze. While carbuncles can form on any part of the body, their acute and more widespread nature differs from the chronic, recurrent discharge around the anus described by the patient.

 

Option C. Boil: A boil, or furuncle, is a skin infection that starts in a hair follicle or oil gland. It typically starts as a reddened and tender area, which becomes hard and then softens as it fills with pus. Boils can occur anywhere on the body, but they're more common on the face, neck, armpits, buttocks, and thighs. Again, given the chronic and recurrent nature of the patient's symptoms specifically around the anus, a singular boil wouldn't match this presentation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A fistula in ano is an abnormal tract that typically develops between the anal canal and the perianal skin, usually due to a previously untreated or inadequately treated abscess.
  • The chronic and recurrent nature of symptoms like discharge and pain around the anus is a hallmark of this condition.

questions.text: Which of the following inclusion bodies are seen in Alzheimer's Disease? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Hirano bodies

 

Explanation: 

 

Hirano bodies are eosinophilic rod-shaped intraneuronal inclusion bodies found in Alzheimer's disease. They represent actin aggregates found within neurons, particularly in the hippocampus. These inclusions are one of the characteristic microscopic findings in Alzheimer's disease, along with the more prominent neurofibrillary tangles (composed of hyperphosphorylated tau protein) and amyloid plaques (composed of Aβ peptide). Hirano bodies are not specific to Alzheimer's disease but are commonly observed in this condition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bunina bodies - These are small eosinophilic cytoplasmic inclusions found in motor neurons in amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS). They are not characteristic of Alzheimer's disease.

 

Option B. Lewy bodies - These are eosinophilic intracytoplasmic neuronal inclusions composed of α-synuclein. They are the hallmark of Parkinson's disease and Lewy body dementia, not Alzheimer's disease. They appear as round eosinophilic inclusions in the substantia nigra and other regions.

 

Option D. Lafora bodies - These are intracytoplasmic inclusions composed of polyglucosan found in Lafora body disease, a rare form of progressive myoclonic epilepsy. They are not associated with Alzheimer's disease.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Hirano bodies are actin-containing eosinophilic rod-shaped inclusions found in neurons in Alzheimer's disease, particularly in the hippocampus, representing one of several characteristic microscopic findings alongside the more diagnostically significant neurofibrillary tangles and amyloid plaques.

choices.text: Give aspirin and discharge the patient

questions.text: A 64-year-old male presents to the emergency department with chest pain radiating to the left arm and shoulder for the past 20 minutes. The ECG demonstrates ST-segment depression, and troponin levels are positive. What is the next best step in the patient’s management? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Give aspirin + clopidogrel

 

Explanation:

 

The patient presents with Non-ST-Elevation Myocardial Infarction (NSTEMI), characterized by:

 

  • Chest pain radiating to the arm
  • ST-segment depression on ECG
  • Positive troponins

 

Initial management follows the MONA-B protocol, and dual antiplatelet therapy (aspirin + clopidogrel) is the first step.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aspirin alone and discharge: Incorrect, as NSTEMI requires hospital admission and further evaluation

 

Option C. Thrombolysis: Contraindicated in NSTEMI (only indicated for STEMI)

 

Option D. Stress test: Contraindicated in acute coronary syndrome

 

Educational Objective:

 

NSTEMI management includes dual antiplatelet therapy (aspirin + clopidogrel), and thrombolysis is contraindicated.

questions.text: A young boy came to Derma OPD with complaints of severe itching at night. On examination, burrows are seen over intertriginous areas, axillae, umbilicus, and between digits. The disease is transmitted by? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Mite

 

The boy's symptoms, including severe nocturnal itching and the presence of burrows in specific body areas (intertriginous regions, axillae, umbilicus, and between digits), are classic signs of scabies. Scabies is a skin condition caused by infestation with the itch mite Sarcoptes scabiei var. hominis. The mite burrows into the skin, causing intense itching, especially at night. The areas affected (often referred to as the circle of Hebra) are characteristic for scabies.

 

 

Circle of Hebra

 

 

Mites

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Louse: Lice infestation, known as pediculosis, typically causes itching but does not present with burrows in the skin or nocturnal itching. Lice infest hair and clothing rather than burrowing into the skin.

 

Option B. Tick: Ticks are ectoparasites that attach to the skin and can transmit various diseases, such as Lyme disease. However, they do not cause the characteristic burrows or intense nocturnal itching seen in scabies.

 

Option D. Flea: Flea bites cause itchy red spots, primarily on the lower legs, but fleas do not burrow into the skin or cause the described distribution of burrows.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Scabies is caused by the mite Sarcoptes scabiei var. hominis, which burrows into the skin, causing intense itching, particularly at night, and burrows in characteristic areas such as the axillae, umbilicus, and between the digits.

questions.text: What is occipitomental view also known as? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Water’s view

 

Occipitomental view is also called Water's view.

 

Water's view: The patient's head is positioned such that the nose and the chin touch the film while the X-rays are projected from backward.

 

Structures seen in Water's view are:

 

  • Maxillary sinuses (seen best)
  • Frontal sinuses
  • Sphenoid sinus (if the film is taken with open mouth)
  • Zygoma
  • Zygomatic arch
  • Nasal bone
  • Frontal process of maxilla
  • Superior orbital fissure
  • Infratemporal fossa

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Towne's view - Typically used for imaging the skull, particularly the occipital bone and foramen magnum.

 

 

Structures seen – 

Arcuate eminence

Superior semicircular canal

Mastoid antrum

Internal auditory canal

Tympanic cavity

Cochlea

External auditory canal

 

Clinical application – Acoustic neuroma, Petrositis

 

Option C. Law's view - Generally related to imaging of the shoulder or elbow, not applicable here.

 

Option D. Stenver's view - A radiographic projection used primarily for detailed imaging of the mastoid process and middle ear structures.

Structures seen –

Arcuate eminence

Internal auditory meatus

Labyrinth with vestibule

Mastoid antrum

Cochlea

Entire petrous pyramid

 

 

Educational Objective:


Water's view is crucial for diagnosing sinus-related pathologies, especially those affecting the maxillary and frontal sinuses. It is a fundamental technique in sinus imaging protocols, providing critical information for the diagnosis and management of sinus conditions.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 493

questions.text: Benzathine penicillin is given for the treatment of rheumatic fever. This is which level of prevention? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Secondary level

 

Secondary prevention involves the early detection and treatment of a disease to prevent its progression.

 

In the context of rheumatic fever, if a child has already developed the condition, benzyl benzathine penicillin (BBP) is administered to prevent further complications, such as rheumatic heart disease. This treatment is given in regular doses (1.2 million units in adults or 0.6 million units in children; every 3 weeks) over a period of 5 years or until the child is 18 years old, whichever comes later. This approach is aimed at treating the condition and preventing its worsening, which characterizes secondary prevention.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Primordial level: This level focuses on preventing the emergence of risk factors in a population. It is not relevant to the treatment of an existing condition like rheumatic fever.

 

Option B. Primary level: This involves preventing the onset of disease in at-risk individuals. In this context, primary prevention would involve giving penicillin to prevent the initial occurrence of rheumatic fever in a child with a streptococcal sore throat.

 

Dose of BBP - 1.2 million units in adults or 0.6 million units in children; single dose; IM stat.

 

Option D. Tertiary level: Tertiary prevention is aimed at reducing the impact of an ongoing illness that has lasting effects. This would involve rehabilitation and managing chronic complications, which is not the primary aim of benzathine penicillin treatment in rheumatic fever.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Secondary prevention involves the treatment of existing conditions, such as rheumatic fever, to prevent further complications.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child with a previous history of GTCS presents with convulsions which are ongoing since 45 minutes. What should be the appropriate management of this patient? (Fmge Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lorazepam followed by levetiracetam.

 

In the case of a prolonged seizure such as status epilepticus, immediate seizure termination is critical. Lorazepam is a preferred initial treatment due to its rapid onset of action in stopping seizures. After the acute phase is managed, levetiracetam can be used for ongoing seizure control. This combination makes option (a) the most appropriate choice for the described scenario.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Valproate followed by Gabapentin: Valproate is an effective antiepileptic drug, but it's not typically the first choice for acute seizure termination in the emergency setting of status epilepticus. Gabapentin is used as a maintenance therapy for seizures but not in the acute setting.

 

Option C. Ethosuximide followed by Gabapentin: Ethosuximide is used primarily for absence seizures and is not appropriate in the acute management of status epilepticus. Gabapentin, as mentioned, is for maintenance therapy.

 

Option D. Carbamazepine followed by Gabapentin: Carbamazepine is used for the treatment of epilepsy but is not the drug of choice in the acute management of status epilepticus. Gabapentin, again, is for longer-term control.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lorazepam is a benzodiazepine and is one of the first-line treatments for the acute management of seizures, particularly in status epilepticus. Following the control of immediate seizures with lorazepam, levetiracetam can be used as maintenance antiepileptic therapy.

questions.text: A patient had a history of TIA and was admitted. 48 hours later he developed severe respiratory difficulty and fever. What is the probable cause? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hospital Acquired Pneumonia

 

Hospital-acquired pneumonia (HAP) is defined as pneumonia that occurs 48 hours or more after admission to a hospital and was not present at the time of admission. In this case, the patient developed severe respiratory difficulty and fever 48 hours after being admitted, which fits the definition of HAP. This type of pneumonia is typically caused by bacteria that are more resistant to antibiotics compared to those causing community-acquired pneumonia. Early identification and treatment are crucial for better outcomes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. ARDS (Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome): ARDS can cause severe respiratory difficulty and is often associated with significant illnesses or injuries, but the timeline and presence of fever in this case are more consistent with an infection like pneumonia.

 

Option C. Community Acquired Pneumonia: This type of pneumonia occurs outside of a healthcare setting or within 48 hours of hospital admission. Given that the symptoms developed 48 hours after admission, it is not classified as community-acquired.

 

Option D. Aspiration Pneumonia: Aspiration pneumonia occurs when food, liquid, or vomit is inhaled into the lungs, leading to infection. While it can occur in hospitalized patients, the timing and presentation in this case are more suggestive of hospital-acquired pneumonia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pneumonia developing 48 hours or more after hospital admission is classified as hospital-acquired pneumonia (HAP).

questions.text: A 10-year-old male child came to the casualty with difficulty in walking and pain in the perianal region. On subjecting the specimen from the perianal region to a test, yellow needle-shaped crystals are seen under the microscope. What is the test done? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Barberio’s Test

 

As the crystals are seen under the microscope, this indicates that it is a microchemical test.

 

Barberio’s test

 

  • Reagent: Picric Acid
  • Component of semen detected: Spermine (secreted from prostate gland)
  • Shape of crystals: Yellow needle shaped crystals of spermine picrate.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Florence test

 

  • Reagent: KI + I2 + H2O
  • Component of semen detected: Coline (secreted from seminal vesicles)
  • Shape of crystals: Dark Brown rhombic crystals of choline iodide (resemble hemin but larger than hemin crystals)

 

 

Option C. Hemin (Teichmann’s) test:

 

  • Reagent: NaCl + acetic acid
  • Brownish-black rhombic crystals of hematin chloride
  • Negative in old stains or washed or treated with chemicals

 

 

Option D. Acid phosphatase test: It’s a non-cellular Semen Markers i.e. markers are specific and unique to seminal plasma but independent of spermatozoa.

 

Finding a significantly elevated acid phosphatase level is consistent with the presence of semen. Undiluted semen has an acid phosphatase level of 340–360 Bodansky units/ml. A value of > 100 Bodansky units with/without motile sperms indicate that ejaculation occurred within 12 h of examination. Level decreases with time after intercourse, and there is little chance of identifying it after 48 h.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Microchemical tests for Semen: Florence and Barberio test (Both are presumptive tests)

 

Microchemical tests for Blood: Teichmann’s and Takayama test (Both are confirmatory tests)

 

Non-cellular Semen Markers: Acid phosphatase test (quantitative), Prostate specific antigen or PSA (p30)

questions.text: The greenish-black color of the first stool in the newborn is due to: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Biliverdin 

 

Meconium is a dark and sticky substance that is normally present in a newborn's intestine at birth and is excreted in the feces after birth. It is first detected in the ileum at around 70-85 days of fetal life and fills the colon and lower ileum late in the 4th month of gestation. The greenish color of meconium is due to bile pigments excreted by the biliary tract, mainly biliverdin, which is formed from the oxidation of bilirubin.

 

  • Biliverdin is responsible for the greenish-black color of the first stool (meconium) in newborns. Biliverdin production starts later in gestation or closer to delivery, perhaps due to a biochemical switch related to the bilirubin oxidation system.
  • Bilirubin is responsible for the yellow color of stools and neonatal jaundice, but not for the greenish-black color of the first stool.
  • Meconium itself is the first stool of the baby, which contains biliverdin, giving it the greenish-black color.
  • Gut flora: Newborns do not have gut flora at birth, so it is not responsible for the greenish-black color of the first stool.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bilirubin: Bilirubin is responsible for the yellow color of stools and neonatal jaundice, but not for the greenish-black color of the first stool.

 

Option C. Meconium: Meconium is the substance itself, not the cause of its greenish-black color. The color is due to biliverdin.

 

Option D. Gut flora of neonate: Newborns do not have gut flora at birth, so it is not responsible for the greenish-black color of the first stool.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The greenish-black color of the first stool (meconium) in a newborn is due to biliverdin, a bile pigment.

questions.text: A patient comes to the casualty with organophosphate poisoning. He was started on atropine infusion and pralidoxime. After 2 hours, the patient had a sudden rise in temperature. What is the likely cause of fever? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Atropine toxicity

 

The most likely cause of fever in this patient is atropine toxicity.

 

The clinical scenario is of organophosphate poisoning and patient was started on atropine infusion and pralidoxime.

 

Atropine is a non-specific muscarinic receptor blocker, but not the nicotinic effects.

 

A/E of Atropine include –

 

  • ↑body temperature (due to ↓sweating)
  • ↑ HR
  • Dry mouth, Dry & flushed skin
  • Cycloplegia
  • Constipation
  • Disorientation
  • Can cause acute angle-closure glaucoma in older adults (due to mydriasis)
  • Urinary retention in men with prostatic hyperplasia
  • Hyperthermia in infants

 

Pralidoxime is given as an adjuvant to atropine in cases of organophosphate poisoning. It does not increase body temperature.

 

Hence, the sudden rise in body temperature is most likely attributed to Atropine Toxicity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Side effect of pralidoxime: Pralidoxime is used as an adjuvant in the treatment of organophosphate poisoning to reactivate acetylcholinesterase. It does not typically cause hyperthermia or significantly affect body temperature.

 

Option C. Due to organophosphate poisoning: Organophosphate poisoning typically causes symptoms due to excessive acetylcholine, such as sweating, salivation, bronchorrhea, bradycardia, and muscle fasciculations. It does not typically cause a sudden rise in temperature as described in this scenario.

 

Option D. Idiopathic: An idiopathic cause is one that arises spontaneously or for which the cause is unknown. Given the context of the medication administration and known side effects, the fever is more likely due to atropine toxicity rather than an unexplained cause.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: In arterial blood gas analysis which one of the following is derived or calculated? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Bicarbonate

 

Explanation:

 

In arterial blood gas (ABG) analysis, we measure specific parameters directly from the arterial blood sample. The directly measured values include:

 

  • pH: The measure of hydrogen ion concentration, indicating the acidity or alkalinity of the blood.
  • pCO2: The partial pressure of carbon dioxide in the blood, indicating how well CO2 is being eliminated from the body.
  • pO2: The partial pressure of oxygen in the blood, indicating how well oxygen is being absorbed from the lungs.

 

Bicarbonate (HCO3-), however, is not directly measured in ABG analysis. Instead, it is derived from the measured values using the Henderson-Hasselbalch equation or calculated from the blood gas analyzer. Along with bicarbonate, base excess or base deficit values are also derived to assess the metabolic component of the acid-base balance.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. pH: This is a measured value that indicates the hydrogen ion concentration in the blood.

 

Option B. pCO2: This is a measured value representing the partial pressure of carbon dioxide in the blood.

 

Option C. pO2: This is a measured value representing the partial pressure of oxygen in the blood.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In arterial blood gas analysis, bicarbonate is a derived or calculated value, whereas pH, pCO2, and pO2 are directly measured parameters.

questions.text: A 35-year-old farmer is bitten by a scorpion. Which of the following acts as a physiological antidote to scorpion venom? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Prazosin

 

Antidote for scorpion venom: Prazosin acts as a physiological antidote for scorpion venom.

 

Effects of scorpion venom: hemolytic and neurotoxic

 

Symptoms of scorpion venom

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Physostigmine: A cholinesterase inhibitor used to treat anticholinergic toxicity. It is not effective against scorpion venom.

 

Option B. Norepinephrine: A vasopressor used to treat severe hypotension. It is not suitable as an antidote for scorpion venom, which can cause hypertension and other systemic effects.

 

Option D. Atropine: An anticholinergic drug used to treat bradycardia and certain types of poisonings. It is not effective against scorpion venom.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Prazosin acts as a physiological antidote for scorpion venom by counteracting the severe cardiovascular and systemic effects induced by the venom.

choices.text: Fluorescein dye - visualised under cobalt blue filter
Fluorescein dye - visualised under green filter

questions.text: What is the dye and filter used as seen in the image?  (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Fluorescein dye - visualised under cobalt blue filter

 

he most likely correct combination for fluorescein dye visualization is Fluorescein dye - visualized under cobalt blue filter. Fluorescein is a yellow dye that, when applied to the eye, emits a bright green fluorescence when illuminated with blue light from a cobalt blue filter. It's commonly used in ophthalmology to detect corneal abrasions, ulcers, or foreign bodies and to assess contact lens fit.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lissamine Green dye - visualized under a green filter: Lissamine Green is a dye that stains devitalized cells and mucous filaments and is used to visualize damage to the conjunctiva and cornea, particularly in dry eye syndrome. It is typically observed under white light, not a green filter, so this combination is not standard.

 

Option C. Lissamine Green dye - visualized under a cobalt blue filter: This is not the standard practice for visualizing Lissamine Green dye. This dye is usually observed under white light, as the cobalt blue filter is specifically used to excite fluorescence from fluorescein dye.

 

Option D. Fluorescein dye - visualized under a green filter: Fluorescein dye is usually visualized under a blue light, not a green filter. When fluorescein is viewed under a green filter, the fluorescence is typically not visible because the green filter would block the green fluorescence emitted by the fluorescein dye.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

In ophthalmology, different dyes and filters are used to aid in the diagnosis of various conditions. Fluorescein dye is visualized using a cobalt blue filter, which causes it to fluoresce and highlights areas of corneal compromise. It is crucial to use the appropriate filter for each dye to accurately diagnose and assess ocular surface disorders.

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl is seen for primary amenorrhea. She has not development of breasts or hair in the pubic or axillary region. Her height is 155cm and her weight is 48 kg. She has bilateral inguinal masses. On USG examination, the uterus, fallopian tube, and ovary are absent. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hypergonadotropic hypogonadism

 

Explanation:

 

  • The diagnosis based on the given clinical scenario is hypergonadotropic hypogonadism.
  • In this question, bilateral inguinal masses (undescended testis), absent ovary, also there is absent uterus and fallopian tubes, all pointing to a conclusion that patient can be of XY karyotype. Because if female reproductive tract is absent, there must be mullerian inhibiting substance present which comes from Y chromosome.
  • Hypergonadotropic hypogonadism can occur in disorders such as FSH or LH receptor mutations.
  • Now, in a XY individual with a defect in LH/hCG receptor, testis’ Sertoli cells will produce Anti-mullerian hormone which will not let uterus, fallopian tube, cervix, upper vagina to develop. Leydi cells will not produce testosterone due to which wolffian duct development is impaired and the testes fail to descend. They appear female at birth and at puberty present with primary amenorrhea. They lack breast development and pubic hair development.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Complete androgen insensitivity syndrome: Androgen insensitivity syndrome individuals have normal breast development.

 

Option C. Turner syndrome: Turner's syndrome karyotype is XO.

 

Option D. Polycystic ovary syndrome: In Polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS) ovary and uterus is present, so can’t be answer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hypergonadotropic hypogonadism can present as primary amenorrhea with absent uterus, fallopian tubes, and ovaries in an XY individual, with bilateral inguinal masses indicating undescended testes.

questions.text: All of the following muscles are derivatives of the first pharyngeal arch, except: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Levator veli palatini

 

Levator veli palatini: The muscle responsible for elevating the soft palate, playing an essential role in swallowing. It prevents food and liquids from entering the nasopharynx during swallowing. This muscle is not derived from the 1st pharyngeal arch but from the 4th pharyngeal arch. It is innervated by the pharyngeal plexus, with contributions primarily from the vagus nerve (CN X).

 

First pharyngeal arch gives rise to:

 

  • Muscles of mastication (temporalis, masseter, lateral and medial pterygoids)
  • Mylohyoid
  • Anterior belly of digastric
  • Tensor tympani
  • Tensor velipalatini and
  • Anterior 2/3 of tongue.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Medial pterygoids: It is one of the muscles of mastication which assists in elevating the mandible and plays a role in the side-to-side movement of the jaw. It originates from the medial pterygoid plate of the sphenoid bone and the pyramidal process of the palatine bone and inserts into the medial surface of the mandible. The medial pterygoid is derived from the 1st pharyngeal arch and is innervated by the mandibular branch of the trigeminal nerve.

 

Option C. Lateral pterygoids: Like the medial pterygoid, it is also a muscle of mastication which depresses the mandible and side-to-side jaw movements. The muscle has two heads, superior and inferior, and it inserts into the neck of the mandible and the articular disc of the temporomandibular joint. Derived from the 1st pharyngeal arch, it is innervated by the mandibular branch of the trigeminal nerve.

 

Option D. Tensor veli palatini: It is responsible for tensing the soft palate and assists in opening the auditory (Eustachian) tube, equalizing the pressure between the middle ear and the nasopharynx. This muscle is derived from the 1st pharyngeal arch and is unique among the palatal muscles because it is innervated by the mandibular branch of the trigeminal nerve.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: What is the latest online software introduced by the government under the national tuberculosis elimination program (NTEP) to monitor patients with tuberculosis? [NEET PG 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) NIKSHAY

 

  • NIKSHAY is the latest online software introduced by the Indian government under the National Tuberculosis Elimination Program (NTEP) to monitor and manage patients with tuberculosis. This software facilitates the tracking of TB patients from diagnosis through treatment, ensuring that all cases are adequately monitored to achieve the goal of TB elimination.
  • NIKSHAY (Nikshay) aims to improve the surveillance, monitoring, and treatment of TB patients by providing a centralized platform for data collection and management. It enables health workers to record details of TB cases, track patient progress, and ensure that treatment protocols are followed, which is crucial for the effective management of TB.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. NISCHAY:   This refers to a pregnancy test kit and is unrelated to the monitoring of TB patients.

 

Option C. E-DOTS:  Electronic Directly Observed Therapy (eDOT) aka Virtual Directly Observed Therapy, is an approach for treating TB where healthcare providers observe patients taking their medication through real-time or prerecorded video.

 

Option D. NIKUSTH:  This software is used for monitoring leprosy patients, not tuberculosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

NIKSHAY - Monitoring TB patients.

 

NIKUSTH - Monitoring leprosy patients.

                                          

NISCHAY - Pregnancy test kit.

 

E-DOTS - Virtual Directly Observed Therapy DOT.

questions.text: Knuckle Bender Splint is used for: (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans: B. Ulnar Nerve Palsy

 

Knuckle Bender Splint is specifically used for ulnar nerve palsy to prevent or correct claw hand deformity. In ulnar nerve palsy, there is paralysis of the medial two lumbricals (which normally flex the metacarpophalangeal joints and extend the interphalangeal joints), leading to hyperextension at the metacarpophalangeal joints and flexion at the interphalangeal joints. The knuckle bender splint helps maintain the metacarpophalangeal joints in flexion, preventing the characteristic claw hand deformity.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Radial Nerve Palsy - This requires a cock-up splint (not knuckle bender) to support the wrist in extension and prevent wrist drop, which is the characteristic deformity in radial nerve palsy due to paralysis of wrist extensors.

 

Option C. Volkmann's Ischemic Contracture - This condition results from forearm compartment syndrome and requires different management approaches including fasciotomy in acute stages and various reconstructive procedures later, not a knuckle bender splint.

 

Option D. CTEV (Congenital Talipes Equinovarus) - This congenital foot deformity is managed with serial casting (Ponseti method) followed by bracing, not with a knuckle bender splint which is designed for hand deformities.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The knuckle bender splint is specifically designed to maintain metacarpophalangeal joints in flexion to prevent or correct claw hand deformity in ulnar nerve palsy, while different splints like cock-up splints are used for other nerve palsies affecting the hand.

questions.text: Sour taste is mediated by:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) TRPV1 Channel

 

Fig: Signal transduction in taste receptors: Salt and sour tastes are mediated via the epithelial sodium channel (ENaC). This receptor has two subunits (a and g), each crossing the membrane twice, resulting in intracellular N and C termini (NT, CT). Salt is sensed following Na+ movement; sour is mediated by movement of H+. Sweet, bitter, and umami tastes are sensed via G-protein-coupled receptors that span the membrane seven times and have varying lengths of CT and NT (represented as ribbon structures). Sweet tastes are detected by the T1R2 and T1R3 families, bitter and umami tastes are detected by the T2R family and mGluR4, respectively.

 

Fig: Receptors on nociceptive unmyelinated nerve terminals in the skin. Nociceptive stimuli (eg, heat) can activate some receptors directly due to transduction of the stimulus energy by receptors (eg, transient receptor potential (TRP) channel TRPV1) or indirectly by activation of TRP channels on keratinocytes (eg, TRPV3). Nociceptors (eg, mechanoreceptors) can also be activated by the release of intermediate molecules (eg, ATP), ASIC, acid-sensitive ion channel; P2X, ionotropic purinoceptor, P2Y, G-protein-coupled purinergic receptor.

 

Sour taste is primarily mediated by the detection of H+ ions, which are present in acidic substances like citric acid. These H+ ions activate ion channels rather than G-protein-coupled receptors (GPCRs). Specifically, the TRPV1 (Transient Receptor Potential Vanilloid Receptor Type 1) channel and acid-sensitive ion channels are involved in mediating the sour taste. These channels open in response to the presence of H+ ions, allowing the ions to enter the taste cells, which leads to the perception of a sour taste.

 

Metabotropic receptors, which involve GPCRs, mediate other taste modalities like sweet, bitter, and umami but are not involved in sour taste. The GPCR T1R1 and T1R3 are specifically involved in the sweet and umami taste pathways.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Metabotropic Receptor: This type of receptor is associated with GPCRs and mediates taste sensations like sweet, bitter, and umami. It is not involved in sour taste, which is mediated by ion channels.

 

Option C. GPCR T1R1: This receptor is part of the GPCR family and is involved in detecting umami (savory) tastes, not sour tastes.

 

Option D. GPCR T1R3: This receptor is also a part of the GPCR family and contributes to the detection of sweet and umami tastes, not sour tastes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sour taste is mediated by the activation of ion channels, particularly the TRPV1 channel and acid-sensitive ion channels, in response to H+ ions from acidic substances

questions.text: Identify the marked chamber? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Left atrium

 

Explanation:

 

The radiological image shows a transverse section of the heart.

 

In a CT scan taken with the patient lying supine, the right atrium and right ventricle will be seen on the front side, while the left atrium and left ventricle will be at the back. The base (posterior surface) of the heart is mainly formed by the left atrium (two-thirds) and the right atrium (one-third).

 

In the image, the vertebra is at the back, and the aorta is on the left side in front of the vertebra. The esophagus is closely related to the base of the heart, particularly the left atrium. The chamber marked in the question is the one just in front of the esophagus is the left atrium.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Right atrium: The right atrium is towards the right side and forms the right border of the heart in this view.

 

Option C. Right ventricle: The right ventricle lies on the front side along with the right atrium. It forms the sternocostal surface of the heart. The marked chamber is at the back, so it cannot be the right ventricle.

 

Option D. Left ventricle: The left ventricle lies next to the left atrium at the back in this transverse section. However, the marked chamber is the one closest to the esophagus, which is the left atrium, not the left ventricle.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a transverse CT section of the heart, the right atrium and ventricle are seen anteriorly, while the left atrium and ventricle are seen posteriorly.

questions.text: Identify the condition. (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Jejunal atresia

 

The image provided shows a characteristic "triple bubble" sign, which is indicative of jejunal atresia. Jejunal atresia is a congenital condition where there is an absence or closure of a portion of the jejunum, leading to intestinal obstruction.

 

The radiographic finding of the triple bubble sign is due to the accumulation of gas in the stomach, duodenum, and the proximal jejunum, which are isolated by the atresia from the rest of the intestines. This results in three distinct gas-filled areas visible on the X-ray, hence the term "triple bubble."

 

In the context of the provided options, the diagnosis is most consistent with jejunal atresia based on this radiographic sign.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pyloric stenosis: Pyloric stenosis typically presents with a "single bubble" sign on X-ray, representing gas in the stomach only due to obstruction at the level of the pylorus.

 

Option B. Duodenal atresia: Duodenal atresia presents with a "double bubble" sign, showing two gas-filled areas (stomach and duodenum) separated by the atresia. This is different from the triple bubble sign seen in jejunal atresia.

 

Option D. Intestinal obstruction: While intestinal obstruction can cause various radiographic signs, the specific "triple bubble" sign is most characteristic of jejunal atresia rather than a general obstruction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The "triple bubble" sign on an X-ray is indicative of jejunal atresia, a congenital obstruction of the jejunum.

questions.text: A female presented in dermatology OPD with acne that is not resolving on oral isotretinoin and antibiotics therapy. Which of the following is the next best step among the following options? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Evaluate for hyperandrogenism

 

  • Since the patient is not responding to isotretinoin and antibiotics therapy, syndromes associated with acne should be evaluated and ruled out to reach a diagnosis. One of the important syndrome is HAIR-AN syndrome.
  • Hence, the next best step would be to evaluate for hyperandrogenism.

 

Important Syndromes Associated with Acne:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Looking for dietary triggers: It could be considered, but this should already be taken care of before prescribing isotretinoin and antibiotics.

 

Option C. Checking for antibiotic resistance: This seems an appropriate step but can’t prioritize over ruling out HAIR-AN syndrome in this patient.

 

Option D. Drug triggers are unlikely to be the primary cause of acne patient who is not responding to isotretinoin and antibiotics. Moreover, lesions in Drug-induced acne are monomorphic and comedones are absent.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When faced with a female patient whose acne has not improved with oral isotretinoin and antibiotics, the next best step is to evaluate for hyperandrogenism, which can point to an underlying hormonal cause such as PCOS, necessitating a different treatment approach.

 

References: Williams Gynaecology 4th edition: page no 392-394

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman presented with chronic low back pain. CT scan of the lower back showed the following. Diagnose the condition CT scan image shown? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Spondylolisthesis

 
Spondylolisthesis refers to the slipping or displacement of one vertebra over another. It is commonly caused by a defect or fracture in the pars interarticularis, a part of the vertebra, which leads to instability in the spine. This condition is often visualized as a "slip" on X-rays or CT scans. A characteristic sign is the "beheaded dog" or "Scottish terrier sign," where the neck of the dog (representing the pars interarticularis) appears broken, indicating spondylolysis, which can lead to spondylolisthesis.
