This vertebral slippage is most commonly observed between the L5 and S1 vertebrae.

 

In this case, the CT scan image shows the typical slip of one vertebra over the other, confirming the diagnosis of spondylolisthesis. This condition often leads to chronic back pain and is frequently associated with nerve compression, particularly at the L5-S1 level.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Spinal metastasis: This condition involves the spread of cancerous cells to the spine, leading to bone destruction or pathological fractures. However, it does not present with a vertebral slip as seen in this case.

 

Option B. Paget’s disease: Paget’s disease is a disorder of bone remodeling, which leads to abnormally large, misshapen bones. While it can affect the spine, it does not typically present with vertebral slippage.

 

Option C. Renal osteodystrophy: This condition is associated with chronic kidney disease and affects bone density and structure. While it can lead to skeletal deformities, vertebral slippage (spondylolisthesis) is not characteristic of renal osteodystrophy.

 

Educational Objective:


Spondylolisthesis involves the slipping of one vertebra over another, typically visualized in imaging studies. The "beheaded dog" or "Scottish terrier sign" is a key radiographic feature of this condition.

questions.text: A patient presented with follicular hyperkeratosis on the extensor aspect of the forearm. What is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Phrynoderma

 

Phrynoderma, also known as follicular hyperkeratosis, is a skin condition commonly associated with vitamin A deficiency. It is characterized by the presence of keratotic papules, especially on extensor surfaces such as the forearms, thighs, and buttocks. The deficiency leads to abnormal keratinization of hair follicles, resulting in rough, bumpy skin, primarily affecting areas that are prone to friction or pressure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Darier’s disease: Darier’s disease is a genetic disorder characterized by wart-like blemishes on the body, particularly in seborrheic areas such as the scalp, forehead, chest, and back. It involves keratinization defects and does not specifically present with follicular hyperkeratosis on the extensor forearms.

 

Option C. Eruptive xanthoma: Eruptive xanthomas are yellowish papules associated with hyperlipidemia and usually occur on the buttocks, elbows, and knees. They are due to lipid deposits in the skin and do not involve follicular hyperkeratosis or specifically present on the extensor surfaces of the forearms.

 

Option D. Folliculitis: Folliculitis is an infection of the hair follicles, often presenting with small, red or pus-filled bumps. It is generally caused by bacterial infection and does not present as hyperkeratosis related to nutritional deficiency.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Phrynoderma is linked to vitamin A deficiency and presents as follicular hyperkeratosis, particularly on extensor surfaces like the forearm.

questions.text: Which vacutainer is commonly used to collect blood samples for serum electrolyte analysis? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Green

 

The green-top vacutainer contains heparin (specifically lithium heparin), which is an anticoagulant that prevents blood from clotting while allowing for accurate electrolyte analysis, especially for sodium (Na+), potassium (K+), and chloride (Cl-) levels. 

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Blue: Incorrect. Blue top vacutainer contains sodium citrate and is used for coagulation studies like PT, aPTT. It would not be appropriate for electrolyte analysis.

 

Option B. Yellow: Incorrect. Yellow top vacutainer is used for bacterial culture and HLA typing. It's not suitable for electrolyte analysis.

 

Option D. Purple: Incorrect. Purple/Lavender top vacutainer contains EDTA and is used for complete blood count (CBC), immunohistochemistry studies and ESR testing using the Westergren method. EDTA can interfere with electrolyte measurements.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For serum electrolyte analysis, green-top vacutainers (containing lithium heparin) are the preferred choice as they prevent clotting without interfering with the electrolyte measurement.

 

 

Sequence of blood Drawn - Chalo Bhai, Red yellow Green Light → Go

choices.text: N-acetyl cysteine to replenish glutathione stores
Glucagon to control bradycardia and hypoglycemia
Give sodium bicarbonate to alkalize urine

questions.text: A young female is brought to the emergency department. Attendants inform that she has consumed 100 tablets of aspirin. What should be the next step in management? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Give sodium bicarbonate to alkalize urine

 

Aspirin poisoning (Salicylism)

 

Respiratory Center Stimulation

↓

Hyperventilation

↓

↓CO2

↓

Respiratory Alkalosis → Reversible

↓

Metabolic Acidosis → Irreversible

 

Treatment - DOC is sodium bicarbonate (NaHC03)

  •  Reverses metabolic acidosis
  •  Helps in aspirin excretion

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. N-acetyl cysteine to replenish glutathione stores: N-acetyl cysteine is an antidote for paracetamol poisoning.

 

Option B. Pralidoxime: Pralidoxime is useful in organophosphate poisoning.

 

Option C. Glucagon to control bradycardia and hypoglycemia: Glucagon is antidote in beta-blocker toxicity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sodium Bicarbonate is the treatment of choice in aspirin poisoning, as it helps to alkalize the urine and enhance the excretion of salicylates, while also correcting metabolic acidosis.

choices.text: Pupils react but do not accommodate
Pupils accommodate but do not react

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient came with a history of unprotected sexual intercourse around 20 years ago following which he had developed genital ulcers. Now, he complains of neurological symptoms and visual disturbances. Which of the following will be seen on exposure of his pupils to light? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Pupils accommodate but do not react

 

  • The patient most likely contracted syphilis through unprotected sexual intercourse and later developed neurosyphilis as a consequence (neurological and visual disturbances).
  • Argyll-Robertson pupil, which is a condition characterized by intact accommodation reflex, but absent light reflex in the affected eye. (ARP-PRA)
  • Features of Argyll Robertson pupil (ARP) are bilateral small pupils with the following characteristics:
  1. Accommodation Reflex Present (ARP):  Pupillary constriction when looking at near objects.
  2. Light Reflex absent: Do not constrict when exposed to bright light (i.e., they do not react to light).
  • This is an example of light near dissociation.
  • Neurosyphilis is a manifestation of syphilis infection that affects the central nervous system, which occurs due to the invasion of the central nervous system by T. pallidum and can occur in any stage of syphilis.
  • Clinical features of neurosyphilis include:
    • Fleeting and repetitive lancinating pains, primarily in the legs.
    • Ataxia and gait disturbances due to loss of position sense.
    • Loss of reflexes in the legs.
    • Paraesthesia’s.
    • Bladder disturbances.
    • Acute abdominal pain with vomiting (visceral crisis).

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pupils react but do not accommodate: This is not characteristic of any specific condition and does not describe Argyll Robertson pupil.

 

Option C. Pupils neither react nor accommodate: This indicates more widespread dysfunction of the pupillary muscles and is not specific for neurosyphilis.

 

Option D. Pupils react and accommodate: This describes normal pupillary function, which would not be expected in the context of the described symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Argyll Robertson pupil, characterized by pupils that accommodate but do not react to light, is a hallmark of neurosyphilis. This condition reflects damage to the central nervous system by Treponema pallidum, which affects both the neurological and visual systems.

questions.text: A portion of animal’s intestine is fixed in the Dales chamber. After infusing a drug, changes are seen in intestinal contractility as depicted in the graph. Which of the following agent resembles the effect? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Adrenaline

 

Explanation:

 

The graph shows a decrease in the amplitude of intestinal contractions following the infusion of a drug. This decrease in contractility is indicative of the sympathetic nervous system's effect on the gastrointestinal (GI) tract. Adrenaline, a sympathetic agent, reduces GI motility and contractility, prioritizing the body's resources for a "fight or flight" response rather than digestion.

 

  • Adrenaline (epinephrine) activates the sympathetic nervous system. During stress, adrenaline reduces GI motility by decreasing the contractility of intestinal muscles, which is evident from the decreased amplitude in the graph.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acetylcholine: Acetylcholine is associated with the parasympathetic nervous system, which enhances GI motility and contractility. Therefore, acetylcholine would increase, not decrease, the amplitude of intestinal contractions.

 

Option C. BaCl₂ (Barium Chloride): Barium chloride increases the contractility of smooth muscles, often used in medical imaging to enhance the visibility of the GI tract. The increased contractility would result in an increased amplitude of contractions.

 

Option D. Serotonin: Serotonin increases GI motility and contractility. It plays a significant role in peristalsis by contracting the proximal part of the intestine. Thus, it would also increase the amplitude of contractions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Adrenaline reduces the contractility of intestinal muscles by activating the sympathetic nervous system, resulting in decreased GI motility.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presented to the clinic with a complaint of the feeling of insects crawling under the skin. Which of the following drug abuse can cause the symptoms of this patient?( NEET PG 2020 )
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cocaine

 

The sensation of insects or bugs crawling on or under the skin, known as "formication", is classically associated with cocaine use. While it can also be seen with the use of other stimulants, including amphetamines, it is most emblematic of cocaine intoxication.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cannabis: Typically results in effects like altered perception, increased appetite, and paranoia.

 

Option C. Amphetamine: Another stimulant that can lead to increased energy, euphoria, and sometimes similar tactile hallucinations.

 

Option D. Alcohol: Produces symptoms such as impaired judgment, slurred speech, and incoordination.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Cocaine intoxication can lead to tactile hallucinations, notably the sensation known as formication. This sensation, often described as feeling like bugs crawling on or under the skin, is a classic symptom of cocaine use and can lead to skin picking and resultant lesions. This is also known as cocaine bugs or magnun phenomenon.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 676.
